div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE TROUBLE IN MOROCCO
div.p: "The massacre at Casa Blanca is the most serious outbreak against Europeans that has yet taken place in Morocco, and prompt measures, we hope, have already been taken for the protection of the town and the punishment of the offenders," says the "Manchester Guardian." "An interesting and fairly complete account of what took place has been brought to Tangier by Dr. Merle, who was specially sent by the French Consul at Casa Blanes to report to the French Chargé d'Affaires. On Monday, it seems, the chiefs of certain interior tribes entered the town and demanded of the Governor the immediate stoppage of the harbour works.

"The Governor, who is exceedingly unpopular with the French, gave the tribes.nen the correct answer that these works were undertaken by the authority of the Sultan, but they went away unsatisfied, and in the afternoon some returned and began to arouse the popu| lation," continues the "Guardian." "There was, apparently, no general outbreak against Europeans; the murders were all committed in the neighbourhood of the harbour works. First the light railway line was torn up, and then Europeans who came up to protest, or were passing, were murdered. The driver of the locomotive was singled out for particularly ferocious treatment. After the Europeans - eight about the works--had been killed, no further attacks were made.

"The outbreak differs from others that have preceded it in that it is the first violent protest against the Algeciras Convention. The moral, however, that is drawn by some Madrid papers that the Act should be torn up and a new Conference summoned to make a new one seems to us perverse. Had those clauses in the Act regulating the new police foree been in operation no massacre could have taken place. A few hundred police under French and Spanish officers would have been quite adequate to protect the workmen in the harbour. The first lesson of the disturbances seems to be that Europe must at once put the first twelve clauses of the Act into execution and equip a police force sufficient to protect European subjects from outrage. The policy of the Act was quite clear and, so far as it went, perfectly sound. It left Morocco, outside the treaty ports, to stew in its own juice; it refused to give any Power a mandate to interfere, which ultimately would certainly lead to a general war, the annexation of portions of Morocco, and the infraction of the treaty rights of those Powers who did not choose to join in the scramble for territory. At the same time, in the treaty ports, where the disorder meant danger to European life and property, the Act authorised the raising of police forces under the command of French or Spanish officers.

"The policy of non-interference outside the treaty ports has its inconveniences, but we believe it is sound. Europeans will have to recognise that if they leave the protection or the ports they do so at their own risk ; and in the meantime the Sultan must settle with his rebellious tribesmen as best he can. Whether he stays on the throne or is deposed is no concern of Europe's. But this quarantining of Morocco implies an adequate system of police in the treaty ports, in which Euro: peans have a right to live and carry on their trade. We hope," concludes the "Guardian," " that France and Spain will now set about equipping this force in accordance with their mandate under the Algeciras Convention."

As a result of this outbreak there is to be a French expeditionary force to Morocco of 2400 infantry, a small detachment of artillery, and 301 cavalry. According to the "Times, "Tangier correspondent the native and French papers contain the bitterest attacks upon the Viziers, and call upon the Sultan to rid himself of the men who have brought Morocco into her present unfortunate condition.

On August 4 the authorities of Casa Blanca, says the "Times," "invited the commander of the French cruiser "Galilée to disembark troops, assuring him that no shot would be fired by the Moors. A detachment of 75 men was accordingly landed, but on approaching the town gate were fired upon by a group of Moorish regular troops.... There upon, the "Galilée'' began a bombardment of the fort and the official quarter.. The French cruiser 'De Chayla' now arrived in the barbour and supported the "Galilée,' opening fire upon the tribesmen."

div.p: The annual aquatic sports of the Alexandria Swimming Club have been fixed for the 5th of October

div.head: Shipping and Banks
div.p: A return cricket match between teams from the shipping firms and banks of Alexandria is being arranged and will probably take place on the 27th inst.

div.head: Crime in the Provinces.
div.p: A native farm hand, 26 years of age, has been found assassinated by a gunshot in the fields near Mellaha Another native farm hand in the same locality is suspected of the crime and has been arrested.

div.head: The Brindiel Mall.
div.p: The mail for Europe via Port Said and Brindisi will be made up at the O.P.O., Alexandris, at 3.10 p.m. on Monday for ordinary Correspondence, 2.10 p.m. for registered correspondence, midday for money orders and insured articles and at noon on Sunday for pareels.

div.head: Quarantine
div.p: By decision of the Higher Council of Health of Constantinople the arrivals from Beyrouth are to be subjected to medical examination at the first Ottoman port, and those from the coast between Novrossesk and Sebastopol are to be equally subjected to examination at the first Ottoman port of the Black Sea and at Covak

div.head: Alhambra Theatre
div.p: "La Cicala e La Formica" (the grasshopper and the ant) is billed for to night at the Alhambra Theatre and for to-morrow's matinée the "Orchid" will be staged, "Granatieri" being given in the evening. The management announced that the Galenzo French comedy troupe will shortly make its début at this theatre.

div.head: The Sudan Rains.
div.p: As a result of the heavy torrents of rain the town of Atbara is practically under water. 130 houses were carried away, and 200 fell in. In order to facilitate the draining of the water the governor has ordered a canal to be dug, which will be finished in three days. The director of the railway has placed the magazines and depots of the administration for the protection of their goods,

div.head: Royal Austrian Anniversary
div.p: To-morrow at 9.15 a.m. the 77th birthday anniversary of Emperor Francis Joseph will be celebrated by a high mass at the Coptic Catho lie Church near Ramleh station. A reception will be held afterwards at the Austrian-Hun. garian Consulate by the vice-Consul Dr. Deitl. A solemn mass will also be celebrated at the Church of the Sacred Heart, Cairo, to be followed by a reception at the Diplomatic Agency. M. Wagner will journey from San Stefano for the reception.

div.head: Post Office Robbery
div.p: Yesterday morning the Consular Court of Italy met to try the case of Martini, in the employ of the Post Office, accused of breaking open drawers containing letters on Shum elNessim, and stealing the contents. The Court was presided over by Signor Falqui Cao. After hearing several witnesses, and a brilliant detainee by Maitre 8. Mortera the judges retired and on their return sentenced the Licensed to two years' imprisonment and a fine of 300 francs

div.head: Pickpocketing
div.p: Yesterday evening about 10 o'clock a Syrian roeet went to the Moharrem Bey Station, where he demanded at the booking office the time of the train to Port Said. Placing his hand in his pocket he discovered that it had been picked and that over £3 had been stolen from him. Seizing the nearest of the men who were crowding round him he took him to the caracol where he was searched, but nothing beyond a. a few piastres was found upon him and he was released.

div.head: Sultan's Accession Anniversary.
div.p: On the 1st of September, the anniversary of the Sultans's accession to the throne, the Regent will give a banquet at the Ras el Tin Palace, to which the ministers, the diplomatic agents, the consuls and the high officials of the State will be invited. Noury Bey, acting Ottoman commissioner, will hold a reception. After the banquet an exhibition of fireworks will be given in front of the palace. In Cairo a tent will be erected in the courtyard of the gouvernorat, where the sub-governor will pope his guests. Refreshments will be served. there will be the usual entertainment, consisting of Arabie singing and music ete.

div.head: OBITUARY.
div.p: Col. William Staveley Gordon, retired list, Royal Engineers, died on the 31st alt, aged 44. He was the son of the late Sir Henry William Gordon, K.C.B. He joined the Royal Marine Artillery Sept. 11, 1881, and being transferred to the Corps of Royal Engineers Peb. 15, 1883, became Captain Sept. 30, 1891; Brevet Major Nov. 5, 1896 ; Major April 1, 1900; Brevet Lieutenant-Colonel Nov. 10, 1898; and Brevet Colonel Feb. 10, 1904. He was employed with the Egyptian Army Dee. 16, 1885, to Aug. 9, 1901. He was A.QM.G. in the Egyptian Service October, 1890, to April, 1892; A.A.G. April, 1892, to December, 1892; and Director of Stores January, 1893, to August, 1901. He served in the Sudan operations (Suakin), 1888-89 (wounded), including the action at Gamsizah, in command of the artillery (4th Class of the Osmanieh); action of Toski, also in command of the artillery (twice mentioned in despatches, medal with two clasps and Khedive's star); in the Dongola Expedition, 1896, as Director of Stores (mentioned in despatches, brevet of Major, and Egyptian medal in the Nile Expedition, 1897; and in the Nile Expedition, 1898, including the battle of Khartoum ; also as second in command, Egyptian flotilla (mentioned in despatches, brevet of lieutenant colonel, clasp to Egyptian medal, medal).

div.head:
FINANCIAL ADVISERSHIP
MR H.P. HARVEY APPOINTED
div.p: The appointment was confirmed this morning of Mr. Henry Paul Harvey, C.B., as financial adviser in succession to Sir Vincent Corbett, to date from 1st of October, the date from which Sir Vincent Corbett's resignation takes effect.
This appointment will, we are sure, be received with general approval, for Mr. Harvey is eminently qualified to fill the responsible post to which he has been elected

Born in 1869, Mr. Harvey received his school education at " Rugby, from which school he passed into New College, Oxford, where he had a distinguished University career and fook first class honours in classics.

Mr. Harvey entered the War Office at the age of 24 and became Assistant Principal Clerk. From 1895 to 1899 he was Assistant Private Secretary to Lord Lansdowne, then Secretary of State for War, and in the latter year he became Private Secretary, which post he ocenpied until November 1900. On January 1, 1901 he was created a Companion of the Bath. During 1902 he was Auditor to the Second Army Corps

Mr. Harvey was appointed British Commissioner on the International Financial Commission for the control of Greek Finances with the rank of Secretary of Legation in March 1903, and on September 16,1905 he was appointed British Delegate on the International Commission for the control of the finances of Macedonia. On September 11,1906 he was given the local rank of Councillor of Embassy in the Diplomatie service.
It is expected that Mr. Harvey will arrive in Egypt during the second week of October, about which time Sir Eldon Gorst will return.

div.head: FRENCH EXPLORATION AT ELEPHANTINE.
div.p: At a recent Séance of the French Academy, Monsieur Clermont Gannean gave a complete account of his last winter's Archaeological Expedition to Upper Egypt, which he conducted of behalf of the Ministry of Public Instruction, and which was restricted, by arrangement, to excavations at Elephantine.

M. Ganneau was assisted by M. Cledat, a former pupil who has been exploring in Egypt chiefly among Coptie antiquities for several. years. The report of work achieved gave first importance to two large statues in diorite eo vered with inscriptions of the era of Thutmose III. which are of exceptional interest, both for the history of Egyptian art and for the religious texts graven upon them.

Near to where these objects were found a small sanctuary was discovered decorated | with miniature obelisks, and erected upon ground which contained a cemetery of mummified rams the majority of these interred in granite coffins. The ram mummies are ornamented with highly decorated cartonage cases covered with mythological scenes and theological texts and in some cases gilded.
The presence of this animal necropolis is certainly owing to Khnoum, the ram-headed deity, being the supreme God of Elephantine, and so the ram was specially sacred animal at that city.

M. Clermont Gannean further mentioned his finding a very considerable number of Ostraca, or inscribed potherds, many of them containing hieroglyphic memoranda but the majority, as usual, bearing hieratic, demotie Greek, and Coptie writing.

The chief object of M. Ganneau's visit to Elephantine was to obtain further Aramaie papyri relating to the Jewish colony there, in the time of Persian Dominion, similar to the Mond Papyri edited last year by Messrs. Cowley and Sayce. In this quest M. Ganneau was unsuccessful, but he found more than one hundred Ostraea with Aramaie texts upon them giving receipts and notes of various kinds, and having for their authors the Jewish families whose mere prolix documents are represented by the papyri found two years ago,

M. Clermont Ganneau was somewhat reticent as to the contents of these ostraca in his speech before the Academie Français, reserving a description of them to a special occasion be cause they represent the result of the object of his journey to Egypt, the hoped for discovery of further Aramaie papyri not having occurred.

The presence of a Hebrew community at Elephantine had been proved by the finding of the papyri but it was uncertain precisely which quarter of the ancient tower they resided and to, ascertain this question was most important with the object of making special excavations there in hope of finding remains of the sanctuary of Jehovah mentioned in the papyri, Thanks to the Ostraca having all turned up in a comparatively confined portion of the site of the city the probable situation of the Jewish place of worship is now known.

The finding of the remains of this edifice which it is known was of very small dimensions, and of further relies, perhaps papyri, of the Jewish residents will be the object of a second expedition of M. Clermont Ganneau next winter. Meanwhile the publication of the contents of the Aramaie Ostraca is anxiously awaited by Hebrew Scholars.

div.head:
ALEXANDRIA
BUILDING BYE LAWS
div.p: V.

There is one important point with regard to cost of street improvements which should not be lost sight of and that is, how is the revenue to be obtained. In the olden days the city of London carried out improvements by the imposition of duties on coal and wine. Coal is not largely used in Alexandria but wine is, so here is a source of income by way of, perhaps, the granting of licenses in addition to the import duties. Owners of motor-cars would be, for their privileges, only too glad to pay a very heavy duty if they were asked to do so. Tobacco smokers would also be glad to pay an extra duty for the greater space in which to disperse the clouds of smoke from their fragrant weeds. Every pack of cards, every box of dominoes, backgammon, dice, should pay a goodly tax every time they are used in gambling - they should be taxed, indeed, out of existence when the money now wasted in gambling might to a great extent become available for street improvements. And there would be but little objection to the levying of a general improvement rate, provided the Municipal accounts of income and expenditure were made public and opportunities given to the ratę payers to discuss and veto, if necessary, unwarrantable expenditure.
Before quitting this part of the subject 1 should mention that in some of the German cities some considerable foresight is now exercised on scheduling lands for the extension of their borders.

A notable exception to the usual haphazard fashion of planning a town, or rather of not planning, is the case of Khartoum where the Sudan authorities have wisely planned the whole town with a generous breadth of street beforehand.
2. THE NAMING OF STREETS.

Next to the street itself, its name is of the greatest consequence, if ease of communication and of business is to be thought of at all. Here in Alexandria there are comparatively few who know the name of the street in which they live. I was once asked, with evident surprise, how I came to know the name of the street in which I lived. The kind friends with whom I stayed had been in the house for ten years and had never known the name of the street.

A very common address of the artisans is simply Bab Sidra" a large district of many narrow streets and courts. If you ask for the name of the street in which they live they may tell you that the mosque, so and so, is a street or two away from their street but as to the name of their own street or the number of the house in which they live, they know them not.
This is partly due to the fact that small streets are not named, or when named the names are not placed in distinct positions.

There is nothing more troublesome to the business man who wishes to call on a person who has left his card than to find on reading it the legend-"Mr. Somebody, Alexandria." Let us therefore have our streets distinctly named and our houses carefully numbered and the names and numbers placed somewhere within sight.
3. OPEN SPACES

Some good people imagine that because a street is more shady and because the heat is great, open spaces are not so much needed in Eastern cities as they are in those situated in the more northern and western parts of the world.

The emanations from the human body are the same everywhere and therefore wide open spaces here and there, as parks, squares and the smaller areas contiguous to the houses for light, air and ventilation, are as conducive to health here as they would be in Glasgow or Whitechapel. So let us have plenty of open spaces with municipal trees, flowers and sparkling fountains would cool the air at stated times, while dusty Alexandrians are resting and listening to the sweet strains of the musie which the Municipality would do well to provide and which would enable the people to enjoy the evening hours, and be at the same time an encouragement to musical talent.
4. CONSTRUCTION.
Mention has been made already of the need of a general code of regulations concerning the construction of buildings.

It would be outside the province of these articles to enter fully into the details of construction. The question of mortar and of bond in masonry has already been touched upon. It might be stated here, however, that I have recently explained some work, the failure of which was entirely due to bad workmanship, unsuitable material and very poor mortar.

The quality of the motrar is very keenly inquired into and tested by the surveyors under the London County Council. The minimum proportion of lime and sand are laid down in the Act of Parliament, but this does not prevent the lime being forgotten or nearly forgotten on occasion. Holding the statutory qualifications as district surveyor for London I have, when acting as a deputy, come across cases where, on analysis, very little lime was found in the mortar. In the Alexandrian case, just mentioned, where the failure of the building was due in great measure to the badness of the mortar, it would be found if the mortar were analysed that the lime discovered would be enumerated as a "trace" only. But in this case the lime had been washed out by the baneful habit of the Alexandrian masons who will saturate their work with water, thereby washing the lighter lime away from the heavier sand. In a most informing and valuable paper recently read by Mr. W. J. Dibdin F.I.C. before the R.I.B.A. on the composition and strength of mortar,great stress is laid, naturally, on the importance of the subject, Mr. Dibden having had a very long experience in the testing and examination of mortar.

The ancient Roman builders, masters of organic building, were well aware of this importance. Their mortar was generally good and it is mainly to this fact that many of their works have survived to this day.

In the matter of bond, so essential a principle in building and especially in the matter of high, weight carrying walls, I have been already at some pains to help my friends the Arab masons by writing for them a book on bond in three languages Arabic, French and English. I mention this because I have found that where a mason has followed the instructions given, improved bond has been the result.

Another important point for Alexandria is the shoring of buildings, that is, the propping up of a building while underpinning is being done or new doors or windows are being inserted. There the shoring is crude. In this again I have tried to be of some help to the Arab masons and only two days ago I was called to look at some shoring which a Moslem had carried out in imitation of some which he had been carried out under my instructions, but when I pointed out to him that he had omitted from the shoring an important piece of timber, he merely said "Maafish."

The use of reinforced concrete or béton armé is becoming more common and in Egypt where sand is plentiful will probably become more so. It is essential, therefore, that rules as to the use of this combination of materials should be formulated.
In England the question has for some time received the serious attention of a committee of the Royal Institute of British Architects, to whom were joined several eminent scientists.
The result has been the drawing up of series of regulations and data for calculation with regard to this important subject of reinforced concrete.
The next and concluding paper will deal with the remaining points of the suggested building bye-laws together with some remarks generally as to building in Alexandria.

div.head: PLAGUE IN BEYROUT
div.p: On the 7th instant the Vali of Beyrout, haying received an official notification from the Governor General of the Lebanon, respecting the occurrence of a case of plague at Dikwani - a small village in the Lebanon lying about 2 miles to the North of Beyrout, the bacteriologist of the Lazaretto, Dr. Kehaya was instructed to forth with repair to the spot, to find, however, that the patient had died about an hour before. The bacteriological examination of extracted bobbie matter revealed the existence of the plague microbe. Inoculation was then, resorted to, and afforded a confirmatory evidence. According to the enquiry subsequently instituted it was found that the deceased was a servant in the employ of Dr. Sauma of Beyrout, and that having been taken ill on the 2nd instant, he was sent away to his house in Dikwani, where the disease developed into plague. In consequence of the occurrence of this sporadic case the Board of Health at Constantinople has simply ordered a medical inspection of passengers leaving Beyrout by land or sea. The municipal doctors were to be in charge of the inland bound passengers, while the seabound passengers were submitted to awkward formalities that the sanitary office here, through mistaken zeal and strictness, has been fit to impose. Every pas. senger had to call at the sanitary office to undergo the summary inspection and provide himself with an individual permit, without which he would not be allowed to go on board. As the sanitary office here is not a very spacious building, overcrowding was an inevitable consequence. Besides, this course necessitated considerable trouble and expense to the travelling public, which the sanitary office might have well avoided, while confirming strictly to the principle of the instructions received from the headquarters at Constantinople, and this by causing the medical inspection to be performed on board. Instead of compelling every passenger to go to the trouble and expense of paying one mejidié and a quarter for the guard accompanying his boat to the sanitary office, and to await his turn in an overcrowded office I prior to undergoing the inspection and getting provided with an individual permit, it would have been the more rational course to have had the Sanitary Doctor go quietly sound in his own boat to the different ships in the harbour, pass the passengers of each steamer in review for inspection, then deliver a collective permit to each ship. · Some shipping agents are said to have made representations to the Board of Health against these unnecessary formalities, and the sanitary office has just received instructions to adopt the more rational system of inspection just outlined by us.

div.head:
THE BRITISH ASSOCIATION.
EARLY EGYPTIAN CIVILISATION.
div.p: At the sitting of the Anthropology section of the British Association on Tuesday week, Professor Naville read a paper, illustrated by lantern slides, on "The Beginnings of Egyptian Civilization." He began by asking three questions :- Who were the Egyptians? Were they & native race born in the country which they inhabited, or did they come from abroad as immigrants! And were they a mixed population, and, if so, could we distinguish the various elements which formed the Egyptian nation 11. In answering these questions he observed that the excavations made during the last 20 years by Petrie, de Morgan, and others had revealed to us that the primitive Egyptian presented the same characteristics as the white races which had been established from all antiquity in North Africa, and that their degree of culture had not gone beyond the stone age. The knowledge we now had of these Egyptian aborigines and of their civilization was derived from the contents of the so-called prehistorie tombs, a great number of which contained their dead in the so-called embryonic posture, which was nothing but the sitting posture described by Herodotus as being oustomary with the African population of the Nasamonians. From the pictures of the vases it could be gathered that the primitive Egyptian lived in huts placed on mounds. These huts were surrounded by enclosures in order to shelter the inhabitants from wild animals. At the side was a standard or pole bearing the totem or the god of the village. The men living in these huts were hunters aired with bows and spears. Their animals were those of the desert, ostriches, antelopes, and gazelles. They did not seem to have been agriculturists.

Boats with sails were seen occasionally, showing that they practised navigation and fishing. Their physical type was decidedly not negro, though some anthropologist admitted a negroid influence. They seemed connected with the African nations collected in the Egyptian inscriptions Tamahu and Tehennu, which originally extended further south than at the time of the Pharaohs. There was no reason to dispute the native character of these Africans. Their civilization, which was entirely determined by the nature of the soil and by the climate, was decidedly of African growth. The name of the prehistorie Egyptians was the Anu, who were found on the Upper Nile in Egypt, where they had left their name to An or Heliopolis, one of the oldest cities of the kingdom, and even in Sinai the Anu were not foreign invaders, but were, on the contrary, the native stock which had been subdued by foreign conquerors. The invasion took place in prehistoric times; and with it appeared the hieroglyphic writing. The invaders called their kings falcons or hawks, the symbol of the god Horus. They were the tribe of Horus coming from South Arabia, from the Asiatic land of Punt. The Egyptian sculptures showed only the African Punt, which must have been between Maasowah and Somaliland. Its inhabitants were of the same race as the Egyptians. They were not Semite, but belonged to the Hamitie stock. The victory of the tribe of Horas over the native stoke was commemorated by a festival called the festival of striking the Any, which was celebrated as late as the 18th dynasty. The monuments of the first dynasties gave an idea of the civilization of the invaders. As soon as they appeared it was seen that domestic animals were not imported, but formed the indigenous fauna such as the cow, sheep, and ass, which were domesticated by the newcomers. On the whole elevation seemed to have grown entirely in the last settlement of the invaders. They adopted and improved the rudimentary culture of the natives into whom they infused their more progressive and active spirit. There was one art only which they must have brought from abroad-metallurgy; and in fact the legends spoke of the black smiths who were the companions of Horus. They probably brought from the Nile the papyrus. As for the vine, it might have come from Africa. The first historical king was Menes, who was said to have done a great deal to civilize his subjects. He united under his rule the various tribes inhabiting the country. But he did not destroy their totems or local divinities, which became the great gods of the provinces or names. As conquerors and conquered belonged to the same race, and as there was no religious feud between them, they | ve y soon amalgamated completely and formed one nation with the Egyptians. In conclusion the Egyptians were a nation formed by an indigenous stock of Hamite African origin, among which settled conquerors coming from Arabia, from the same starting point as some of the Chaldeans, and who were also Hamite. The dawn of Egyptian culture was a distinct proof of the great part played by Africa in the history of human civilization, and supported the idea recently put forward that Aryan culture came from the South Professor J. Garstang then gave a short account of his recent exploration in Asia Minor and North Syria.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: "Al Watan" in a leading article says There are so many things in the air of Egyptian politics nowadays bearing upon the same question and pointing to the same moral that it his hard to pass all these things over or suppose that they will go unheeded by the ruling Power whose interests are to some extent at stake. Unfortunately the name of the Khedive is dragged into nearly all these matters because such matters are invariably created by Na tionalist minds, and because these intriguing Nationalists have made it their tank to convince others that they are the favoured party and the loyal friends of the Khedive to the exclusion of every other being under the sun. Whatever they do is immediately attributed to the Khedive, all protests and denials on our part being in vain. Whatever his Highness' says or does is regarded by these Nationalists oiling their own desires and reiterating their own views. It has become absolutely impossible to certain minds to separate between the Khedivial policy and the Nationalist propaganda after the repeated assertions and insinuations of all these years.

This is a most regrettable state of affairs. It is wrong and mischievous. It is grave and dangerous to certain quarters and to the country at large. We have done our best on many occasions to deny the ne lation between the Palace and the lengte of fanaticism, the party of opposition to England and hatred to foreigners. But we -must admit with profound regret that our efforts in this way have been entirely unavailing much to onr disappointment and to the detriment of public interests. The current events and of Nationalist pretensions are too strong for such sincere declarations and plain statements as we are able to make from time to time.

div.head: RAMESES' LITTLE JOKE.
div.p: Your paragraph about the annoyance felt by Egyptian explorers at finding the name of the great Rameses on many antiquities that had existed long before he did, writes Mr. G. R. Cheetham to the "Globe," makes no allusion to the interesting reason that caused this King, and many others, to steal the statues of their predecessors, by causing the cartouche of the person the statue was originally erected to commemorate to be obliterated and their own cartouche substituted. The simple reason was that the ancient Egyptians at one time firmly believed, to quote the words of Dr. Wallis Badge, "that the destruction of a man's name involved the destruction of his whole being," and so involved the loss of all hope of immortality. To guard against this, the great Kings had their statues made of the hardest and most durable stones, and took care that the name, or eartouche, should be deeply cut into it. They did their utmost to multiply the number of these figures, so as to increase the chances of the survival of some of them, and so guarantee the permanence of their name and their own immortality. As Rameses the Great enjoyed one of the longest reigns in history, he had ample opportunities of erecting temples and statues to perpetuate his name. To make assurance doubly sure to be annexed, as is shown by numerous examples in the Cairo Museum, many statues of his predecessors, but although he was a great sinner in this respect, my object in writing is to point out that he was also sinned against. There is a colossal statue of red granite now in the "Portico of the Four Pillars," in the Cairo Museum, which stood for many centuries at Eshminen, bear Jing the cartouches of Menephta, the successor of Rameses II, and supposed to be the Pharaoh of the Exodus. From about 1200 Bc. the ancient Egyptians regarded this magnificent figure as Meneplatel But it really represents Rameses II. When he had it erected, he felt that one day some of his successors would steal it, by destroying the visible cartouches, so, with infinite foresight and considerable humour, he had his cartouche also engraved underneath the base Thanks to this precaution, now some 8,000 years after the statue was stolen by Menephtah, it has been restored to its rightful owner, Rameses, II. If the shades of these two monarchs should chance to meet in the kingdom of Osiris, the laugh will be with the latter.

div.head: EGYPTIAN CIGARETTE, TRADE
div.p: During last month 38,048 kilos of cigarettes were exported from Egypt. as compared with 38,654 kilos in July 1906. From January 1 to July 21 the total export of cigarettes were 271,590 kilos showing a falling off of 190, 486 kilos in comparison with the corresponding period of last year,
News received from Casablanca on the 14th says that 400 Spaniards were landed on Monday. The town and surroundings were calm. (Havas)
Yesterday shells from the cruiser "Gloire" dispersed groups of Moors round about Casa blanca. The inhabitants are slowly returning. (Havas)
About 500 Spanish troops have landed at Casablanca. They are the cause of much friction with the French, who complain of breaches of etiquette, indiscipline, and indisposition to cooperate. (Later)

The Franco-Spanish Governments have arrived at complete agreement regarding the employment of troops at Casablanca. Meanwhile, all correspondents agree that General Drude needs large reinforcements to effect the restoration of peace. (Reuter)
A telegram from Admiral Philibet received yesterday, says that in the opinion of the. authorities in Mazagan the surrounding tribes will not attack the town, which is at present calm. (Havas)

div.head: THE OUTBREAK IN MOROCCO.
div.p: The "Temps" publishes some interesting particulars with regard to Ma el Ainin, the instigator of the recent explosion of anti-for eign feeling at Casablanca and of three previous attacks against French posts in Mauritania.

Although, it says, he is not a Sovereign, since be possesses no fixed territory as his own, he is something more than a spiritual leader, inasmuch as from Senegal to Fez he has adepts who obey him, and whom in certain regions he is able to enrol as hostile bands. He belongs to one of the big families of the Western Sahara, a region famous for the cultivation of Mosul. man studies. At present Ma el Ainin has a great prestige as a "savant", and is said to be the author of 50 volumes. He has already published 12 at Fez on law, theology, sufism, astronomy, astrology, and grammar. The present Sultan-like his father before him-holds Ma el Ainin in great veneration, and has more than once received him at Fez with special honours. The last journey of Ma el Ainin to the capital was a triumphal progress, the Moorish towns being called upon to pay him tribute and to offer him and numerous escorts abundant hospitality. The contributions of Mogador reached 150,000f. (£6,000) Ma el Ainin has founded a religious brotherhood, of which the Sultan is said to be a member. The brothers, whom the Moors call the blae men because they wear a blue cotton staff of which the colours run and stain their bodies, which they never wash, produced a mingled effect of fanaticism and repugnance upon the populations as they passed. Ma el Ainin lives habitually in the Saguia el Hamra, four days journey from Cape Juby, in a region which, owing to its isolation in the desert has hitherto been regarded as inaccessible. But now that French Meharists move about the desert as freely as the nomads that is no longer the case. Already the Meharists of the Saharan oases have opened a good route by the Menakeb from Twat to the Atlantic. When those of | Mauritania have occupied Adrar it will be easy to arrange a safe concerted movement on the Saguia el Hamra. That eventuality, says the | "Temps," ought already to be contemplated.

The eminent economist M. Arthur Raffalo vich, whose annual publication "Le Marché Financier" has just appeared, notes in the section devoted to France certain facts con| cerning the commercial relations of the Powers with Morocco, which, although known to the readers of British Consular reports, have a special interest at the present moment and are far from being generally realized by the European public. In 1905 German trade with Morocco remained stationary at 13,000,000f. |(£520,000), British trade fell back to 37,400,000f. (£1,496,000), and French trade, outstripping that of all other countries, reached 43,400,000f. (£1,736,000), and was 40 I per cent of the whole Moorish trade. There were, of course, several accidental causes to which this state of things was due. In consequence of the previous year's droughts Germany and England, who take over the larger portion of Moorish exports found their share of the trade necessarily diminished, whereas France, whose trade with Morocco is mostly in imports into the country, was not affected. Moreover, money being sought, the Moors devoted all their resources to the purchase of foodstuffs, sugar, flour, &c., which they obtain from France, those purchases being substituted for the cottons of which they normally buy large quantities from England."

But there are permanent causes of the suggestive shifting of the trade statistics, and M. Raffalovich's remarks in this connexion are very much to the point. These causes are the considerable increase of the French colony in Morocco and the growth of regular relations between Morocco and France. There are at present nearly 1,000 Frenchmen at Tangier and increasing groups in the other ports--facts which belie the widespread idea that Frenchmen do not care to settle abroad. There are a number of large representative and honourable French houses, and the growing number of colonists is creating an important movement of trade. Many of the colonists are from Algeria, and, knowing the language and customs of the Arabs, often succeed. where others fail. The 11 French steamship companies trading between French and North African ports, established solely by private enterprise, are also doing much to augment the importance of French trade with Morocco. There is thus a steady increase of Moorish trade with France and Algeria. The figures reached last year 42,807,663f. (£1,712,306), as against 24,549,848f. (£981,993) in the case of England and 7,182,780f. (£287,811) in the case of Germany. In other words, the share of France in the entire trade of Morocco with the world has now exceeded half of the total, Germany's trade is steadily falling, and is not commensurate, says M. Raffalovich with the political activity of that Power.

div.head: IRON IN ANCIENT EGYPT.
div.p: In this section on the same day.

Professor W. Ridgeway opened an interesting discussion on the Beginning of Iron He remarked that formerly it was generally believed that iron was the gift of Africa to mankind, and if not of Africa, then most certainly of Asia. Modern research had shown that Egypt did not use iron nntil about 800 B..., that the Libyans were not using it in 480 B.C., and that the Semitic peoples did not use it from a remote past, but borrowed it comparatively late. He had urged in 1896 and in 1903 that Central Europe was the true centre of the use of iron ada metal, and that it was first diffused from Noxicum. At Hallstatt iron was seen coming into use first to decorate bronze, then to form the edge of cutting implementa; next it for dually replaced bronze weapons and only took new forms of its own. Everywhere else iron as a metal came into use per saltum. Some still imagined that it was used very early in Egypt, because its name occurred in early documents, But this was readily explained, since hematite was known and used very early in Egypt, and the same material was used very commonly in the Ægean long before the Bronze Age. But it was treated not as a metal to be smelted, but as a stone to be ground into axes and beads. The Egyptians thus knew the mineral and had a name for it, which they continued to employ when they had learned its use as a metal from Europe. Others also elung to the belief that iron was worked in Central Africa from a remote time. But in Uganda, which was in touch with Egypt by means of the great lakes and the Nile, iron, as he had been informed by the Rev. J. Roscoe, became first known about four or five hundred years ago. This rendered it very unlikely that the metal was worked until very late in Central Africa. It was certain that the peoples beyond the Caspian, as well as those along the Indian Ocean, did not use iron till quite late, that India herself did not know it at an early date, and that Japan only got it about 700 AD. The earliest mention of iron in Chinese literature was about 400 B.C. There, was evidence that bronze swords were being used till 100 A.D. and that it was only then that iron swords were coming in. It was now clear that the use of iron as a metal was due to Central Europe. | Professor Naville thought that a distinction must be made between the knowledge of iron and its general use. In Egypt, in the Old Empire, there were two of three cases of iron being found, one by Professor Petrie at Abydos of a lump of iron with copper instruments, and another by Mr. Perring, who discovered iron fragments in the Pyramids. In the New Empire iron did not seem to have been commonly used. In the excavations of Deir el-Bahari, were found, there were bronze chisels and bronze foundation deposits, but no iron. In the time of Rekhmare battle axes of iron were imported into Egypt. The general use of iron in Egypt could not be traced before the Greek time.

Professor W. M. Flinders Petrie observed the distinction between the sporadic and the general use of material must be kept in view. Flint was used for economie pur. poses down to the Roman Age in Egypt, although copper was known for 8,000 years before. Bronze was known by 4800 B. C., yet did not come into use till 3,000 years later. Thus iron was known for 4,000 years before it came into economic use. Iron of the periods of 4700, 4200, 3300, 1200, and 1,100 B. e, had been found in Egypt. This sporadieuse strongly supported Professor Ridgeway's view of the use of native iron, for had a process of reduction been invented it was unlikely that it would have lagged for 4,000 years before its common use, whereas native iron might be occasionally discovered and worked by man discontinuously.

div.head: THE HEBREW NOTE IN LITERATURE.
div.p: Mr. G. P. Abbott, in the latest book about Jews, which he entitles "Israel in Europe," has a first chapter on Hebraism and Hellenism, in which he declares without reservation that "Palestine" was the home of reflection, Hellas of speculation. The one country has given us philosophy and Platonic dialogues, the other the prophets and the Mosaic decalogue : the former all argument, the latter all commandment."
HEBRAISM AND HELLENISM.

Quoting this phrase in his Presidential address to the Union of Jewish Literary Societies, Mr. Laurie Magnus suggested that the natural tendency of style to antithesis had misled Mr. Abbott, in his interesting and illuminating work, into a real exaggeration of the contrary character of these two movements. Turning to Dr. Friedländer's study of Maimonides, the great Jewish sage, Mr. Magnus finds a very striking passage which confirms his own belief that there is more Hellenism in the Hebrew genius than is commonly supposed. "Maimonides is explaining the nature of the Hebrew conception of wisdom, and he shows clearly that its content is not exhausted by any such summary as that attempted by Mr. Abbott, for instance, when he tells us that the Law and the prophets are together all commandment,Maimonides is at pains to prove, and the proof is of supreme value if we would form a true conception of the Hebrew note in literature, that the element of commandment in the Jewish writings is only a part of the aim of Jewish teaching, and that wisdom contains not merely obedience bal intelligence as well.

Hence in the interests of truth, I am bound to demur to Mr. Abbott's remarks that "the intellectual freedom which the Greek has claimed from all time, and upou which he has built his noble civilisation, was repugnant to a people swathed in the bands of tradition and distrusting all things that are not sanctioned by authority. It may be correct, as he writes, that the Greeks had no word for faith' but it is not correct, as he leaves his reader to infer, that the Hebrews had no word for intelligence. We are far too apt in my opinion, in contemplating, the elaborate code bequeathed by the Hebrew legislators, to forget the goal of perfection which was aimed at through that code.
INTELLECTUAL FREEDOM OF THE JEW.

Maimonides quotes two verses from the 22nd chapter of Jeremiah - Thus, saith the Lord, let not the wise man glory in his wisdom, neither let the mighty man glory in his might; let not the rich man glory in his riches, but | let him that glorieth glory in this, that he understandeth and knoweth Me'; and the emphasis that is laid on the obligation not merely to accept or to obey, but to glorify understanding and knowledge, is a note which recurs almost more constantly than any other up and down the pages of the Hebrew Scriptures, Mr. Abbott and those who, like him, have adopted with excessive zeal the distinction between Hellenism and Hebraism stop short at the acceptance of the tradition and ignore the true 'Hokmah' of the Hebrews, which includes demonstration by reason. It is obvious that this intellectual exercise ---this reasonable demonstration of truths revealed to the imagination, though not to experience--can only be practised by men of exceptional mental powers.
One of the chief signs of the Hebrew note in literature, said Mr. Magnus, "is a luminous simplicity and directness in the expression of transcendental thought."

For the Aged, Benger's Food is particularly adapted to the enfeebled digestion of advancing years.
For those who are well, Benger's Food is an ideal light meal, dainty and nutritive.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
Coton
div.p: La semaine que nous allons passer en revue n'a été intéressante que dans ses débuts, car, pour ce qui est de l'ensemble, elle n'a guère différé de celles qui l'ont précédée, le résumé final étant, une fois de plus, l'inaction et la faiblesse. Au fond de tout cela, il n'y a toutefois rien de sérieux ou de grave ; mais en somme plus nous allons, plus nous constatons que les mouvements de fermeté ne peuvent guère se maintenir plus de 24 ou de 48 heures, que le marché est très restreint et se laisse influencer par la moindre des choses, que la spéculation brille par son absence on se trouve dans l'impossibilité d'opérer sur une large échelle et que notre précédente appréciation qu'une reprise des affaires basée ne saurait être espérée avant Octobre ou même Novembre n'a rien d'exagéré.

Ce que nous venons de dire n'est certainement pas bien encourageant, mais malheureusement c'est la réalité et sur ce point il n'y a pas de discussion possible. Voici d'ailleurs comment les choses se sont passées depuis notre dernière chronique.

Sur une demande surgit dans la matinée de samedi et qui s'est étendue à la séance de lundi, le marché aux contrats a été relativement actif, et en comparaison de ce que nous étions habitués à voir, les affaires ont eu une certaine importance. Seulement, par suite de la rareté des vendeurs, ceux qui ont tenu à acheter n'ont pu le faire qu'en forçant les cours et c'est absolument à ce fait qu'il faut attribuer l'avance de 1/4 de tallari qui a été enregistrée durant les deux journées susmentionnées.

L'amélioration en question était due aux achats du commerce d'exportation et c'est avec raison que l'on a soutenu cette information ; mais ce qu'il y a de navrant, c'est que cette demande a cessé dès que l'Américain a commencé à baisser sur l'annonce qu'il avait plu dans le Sud-Ouest du Texas et depuis lors nous n'avons fait que faiblir et rester dans le marasme le plus complet, ce qui nous a fait tomber pour un moment à 20 9/32 pour le Novembre

Aujourd'hui, cependant, il y a eu un semblant de fermeté et comine finale c'est à la cote de 20 11/32 que la clôture de la semaine a lien, cours qui réduit à 1/32 la perte subie depuis Vendredi passé. Ce n'est rien en définitive et l'on pourrait à la rigueur même dire que c'est bon, si l'on prend en considération la baisse de New-York et la modération de nos exportations pour la semaine ; mais, d'autre part aussi, le manque d'affaires est pour certaines journées pour ainsi dire absolu et cela constitue toujours un point inquiétant.

La retraite soudaine de la filature pourra paraître quelque peu surprenante; mais en y regardant de près on ne saurait qu'admettre que sa réserve est plus que justifiée par les avis qui lui parviennent de tous les côtés sur l'état et les perspectives de notre récolte. Certes, celle-ci n'est pas encore en poche et il serait peut-être prématuré de vouloir escompter l'éventualité d'une réussite complète avec les risques des brouillards restant à courir ; mais, comme tout le retard a été rattrapé, que dans la Haute-Egypte la cueillette a commencé et que le surplus de la production dans cette partie du pays constitue toujours une certaine compensation aux dégâts qui pourraient survenir dans le Delta, la consommation peut temporiser. Et cela d'autant plus qu'elle s'est déjà assurée les premiers besoins et qu'il n'est pas dit que la circonstance qui, l'année dernière, a, motivé l'emploi de l'Egyptien sur une large échelle, c'est-à-dire la pénurie du bon coton américain, doit se répéter pour la campagne prochaine. L'attitude de la filature, surtout à un niveau aussi élevé en lui-même que le cours de 201, est done chose toute naturelle.

L'Août n'a pas beaucoup attiré l'attention : négligé la plupart du temps, la côte était considérée comme nominale et en réalité ce n'est qu'aujourd'hui et sur une petite demande qui s'est fait jour inopinément qu'il a montré de la fermeté. Le fait est que la clôture a en lieu à 19 31/32, soit avec 3/32 de hausse sur Vendredi dernier. En tous cas, le fait n'a aucune importance, car il ne reste plus que quelques milliers de Cantars de cette échéance et c'est pour cela que toute affaire influence facilement le cours. Du reste, d'ici une semaine, tout aura passé entre les mains de l'exportation et on n'en parlera plus.

Comme nous y avons fait allusion plus haut, les avis de l'intérieur au sujet de la récolte sont exceptionnellement favorables La Haute Egypte nous promet quelques balles d'ici quatre ou cinq jours, tandis que la Basse Egypte nous a déjà envoyé d'assez gros échantillons de curiosité.

Une nouvelle pourtant désagréable a consisté dans l'annonce que les brouillards avaient été signalés dans la Charkieh et dans la Dakahlia. Le fait est vrai, mais les mêmes correspondants qui ont câblé l'information ajoutent que les brouillard Is n'ont pas eu une longue durée et que, dans tous les cas, jusqu'ici ils n'ont causé aucun mal.

L'Intérieur qui avait fait mine de se retirer quand la reprise à 20 1/2 a eu lieu, court maintenant de nouveau après les acheteurs, mais ceux-ci, à leur tour, font les précieux. Ils n'ont pas tort, car, après tout, qui est ce qui pourrait leur enlever la récolte et n'ont-ils pas la chance d'opérer dans de meilleures conditions que, celles existant actuellement quand la marchandise effective sera sur le marché et que les besoins d'argent du cultivateur seront plus pressants ?

Du côté de l'Amérique, on a câblé la disparition de la sécheresse du Texas, mais on l'a signalée au Sud-Ouest du Mississippi. Toute. fois, ce dernier renseignement ne paraît pas sérieux, car les mêmes dépêches ajoutent qu'il *x a lieu de s'abstenir de tout achat pour le moment. C'est édifiant.

En attendant, la crise financière sévit d'une façon intense à New-York et il n'est pas humainement possible que le resserrement moné. taire causé par les valeurs ne se répercute pas sur le marché cotonnier. Les Banques sont en train de prendre leurs précautions, mat lan réalisation de la récolte cotonnière en Amérique exige des millions en masse et ces millions ne ! se trouvent pas là toujours prêts sous la main.
Notre marché du disponible a été d'un calme très prononcé et les affaires connues s'élèvent à un chiffre très limité.

Quant à la côte, elle reste sans changement, sauf pour ce qui concerne le Good fair Mit Afifi qui est demandé et qui monte de 1/8 et le Good Jovanovich qui a dû être payé 1/2 tallari au-dessus de la semaine passée.

Les exportations de la semaine n'ont pas atteint les prévisions et se sont arrêtées à 3600 balles, contre 4600 en 1906. On dit cependant qu'il y a retard pour certains lots et que la différence se retrouvera la semaine prochaine. Cela est possible, mais la question des exportations ne peut plus intéresser le marché pour le moment. La semaine prochaine a été l'année dernière de 4300 balles.

Liverpool a été active pour les égyptiens disponibles, mais peu propice pour ce qui est des prix. Le spot est invariable à 10 3/4, tandis que les futurs perdent de 11 à 12 points au cours de 10 31/64 pour l'Aout.

Les américains, peu animés comme ventes, se trouvent être beaucoup plus malmenés sous le rapport des prix. Le disponible a fini à 7 29 ce qui fait 11 points de baisse, mais les cours sont encore en recul plus sensible pour les futurs que nous trouvons ce soir à 6.78 pour l'Août Septembre et 6,53 pour le Janvier Février, soit respectivement en perte de 15 et | 18 points.

div.head: Graines de Coton
div.p: Il y a bien en quelques arrivages, mais outre la circonstance qu'ils étaient modérés, ils n'é. taient point destinés à la vente et c'est pour cette raison que le marché du disponible a été d'une nullité absolue.

Comme conséquence naturelle de ce fait il n'y a pas en de prix réels pratiqués et la cote journalière que l'on donne aux journaux est à considérer comme nominale. C'est absolument le même cas que la semaine passée. 1 En contrats vieille récolte il n'y a eu que quelques opérations sans importance et le cours de l'août finit à P.T.81 3/4, en attendant que la filière du 22 courant vienne forcer la liquidation du peu qui existe en flottant.
Hull a réduit son prix à £8 2/6, mais même à ce prix il n'y a que des affaires insignifiantes.
La nouvelle récolte a montré une meilleure tenue que l'ancienne, sans être cependant active.
Les 3 mois se tiennent à la côte de P.T. 71 25/40 comme dernière côte.
Pour l'Angleterre il s'est fait quelques ventes à £7 1/3 pour Novembre Janvier,

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIÈRE
div.p: Notre corbeille des valeurs a magistralement débuté lundi par une avance générale de la côte, déterminée d'un côté par l'allure provocante des haussiers et de l'antre par l'abstention à peu près complète des vendeurs qui paraissaient impressionnés par l'optimisme débordant de la majorité spéculative. Dans de telles conditions on conçoit aisément qu'il n'y avait pas besoin d'affaires bien nombreuses ni bien importantes pour donner à l'ensemble des titres une impulsion irrésistible. Les transactions, tonte trois, si elles n'ont pas eu l'envergure des beaux jours, ont formé avec les séances mornes da commencement de l'été un contraste assez frappant, rendu plus sensible encore par l'animation un peu factice qui imprimaient au marché les courtiers emballés. En Agricole, National Bank, Behera, Comptoir, Banque d'Athènes et Union Foncière il y avait des demandes suivies, mais les échanges effectifs portaient principalement sur les petites valeurs, telles que les Estates, l'Investment, l'United et la Delta Land.

Cet emballement des agents de change que nous venons de signaler n'avait pas manqué de nous causer quelques inquiétudes, car assez généralement ces messieurs se trompent dans leurs pronostics, et nous connaissons plusieurs capitalistes spéculateurs qui se sont bien trouvés de vendre leurs paquets chaque fois que la croyance à la hausse ralliait le plus grand nombre de leurs suffrages. Le fait est que le | lendemain le vent avait tourné. Dès l'ouverture les vendeurs, la veille encore introuvables, étaient à la recherche des acheteurs, qui avaient à leur tour disparu. Réalisation de profits, disait-on. Ceux qui ont acheté ces temps derniers à la faveur de la dépression veulent rentrer dans leurs bénéfices; en d'autres termes, les acheteurs de naguère se sont transformés en vendeurs d'aujourd'hui. Ce N'est pas plus malin I que ça. Ceux qui tiennent de tels propos avoueront avec nous que si leurs suppositions sont fondées, l'élément acheteur en se transformant du jour au lendemain en élément vendeur ne fait preuve ni de surface ni de confiance en l'avenir. Faut-il ajouter que cette volte-face générale et subite n'a pas permis aux intéressés de se débarrasser de leurs paquets! Malgré cela, les haussiers ont pu maintenir la cote mais les opérations ont été clairsemées et limitées comme la veille à quelques titres d'ordre secondaire.

Mercredi l'allure n'a pas changé, à cette différence près que les affaires se sont encore raréfiées. Il y avait une tendance évidente à réaliser, sans résultat d'ailleurs, puisque tout le monde avait tourné casaque. Hier, jeudi, fête I de l'Assomption, la corbeille des valeurs est restée fermée. Cependant, les règlements ont eu | lieu comme à l'ordinaire. Ce matin on a ouvert déprimé et cette allure n'a fait que s'accentuer jusqu'à cinq minutes avant la clôture. A ce moment les haussiers, faisait un suprême effort, ont réussi à relever un peu les prix qui étaient tombés assez bas. On n'en a pas moins clôturé à un niveau généralement inférieur à celui de la veille. Quant aux affaires, si elles continuent à diminuer, nous reviendrons bientôt au calme plat de juillet. La pullulation des acheteurs qui encombraient la corbeille la semaine passée a totalement disparu pour faire place à celle non moins encombrante des vendeurs à tout prix qui se trouvant près. que senls dans la corbeille ne peuvent opérer qu'à de rares intervalles et moyennant de coûteuses concessions. C'est toujours aux réalisations de profits qu'on attribue la réaction présente, mais la lassitude, les positions surchargées, les mauvaises nouvelles d'Amérique, l'approche de l'automne et la hausse continue du taux d'escompte n'y sont peut-être pas étrangères.

En résumé, après une avance appréciable lundi, la côte, stationnaire le lendemain et le surlendemain, a cédé aujourd'hui sur la plu| part des valeurs traitées. Le résultat final est que sur une soixantaine de titres inscrits à la cote officielle d'Alexandrie, 20 sont en hausse et 17 en baisse, les autres demeurant stationnaires.

Comme fluctuations remarquables il faut signaler : à la hausse, un gain de 9 fr. sur les Jouissances Eaux du Caire à 192, de 15/16 sur les Ninkovich Hôtels à 14 11/16, de 5/16 sur la Building Lands à 2 9/16, et d'une 1/2 | livre sur l'action Allotment à 2 7/8 ; à la baisse, une perte de 14 frs. sur les Privilégiées Bière du Caire à 146, et de 5 fr. sur les Sucreries à 25. C'est à une demande provenant du Caire qu'il faut attribuer la hausse des Jouissances Eaux du Caire et des Nungovich Ho| D'autre part, la Behera gagne 1/4 à 20 1/2, la Cassa di Sconto 4 tr. à 46, les Bières du Caire 2 fr. les Privilégiées 4 89 et 3 fr. les Dividendes à 38, la Banque d'Athènes 2 fr. a 113 et la fondateur Allotment 10 P.T. à 85. LA Delta Light perd, au contraire, 1/8 à 9 3/4, les Dividendes Tramways 5 fr. à 300, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier 2 fr. à 301 l'ancienne et 258 la nouvelle, lg Delta Land 3/32 à 1 15/16, la Khedivial Mail 1/8 à 3 7,8, la Land Bank 1/4 là 7 1/16, les Estates 3/32 à 3/4, l'Urbaine 1/8 à 35/8, et la fondateur United 1/8 à 2 1 4.

Les autres changements sont insignifiants : la National Bank hausse de 20 1/4 à 20 9/32, les Privilégiées Tramways de 141 1/2 à 143, les Eaux du Caire de 113 à 114, les Markets de 27/9 à 29, la Spinning de 5/16 à 3/8, la Salt & Soda de 18/6 à 18/9, le | Banco de Roma de 104 à 106, le Crédit Franco-Égyptien de 4 3/16 à 4 9/32, la Port Said Salt de 14 à 14/6, les Cotton Ginners de 1 5/16 1 3/8, et la Levico de 7/16 a 15/82, tandis que les Lots Turcs fléchissent de 165 à 164, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 21,9 à 21/6, le Comptoir de 3 à 2 15/16 | l'ancienne et de 2 15/16 à 2 7/8 la nouvelle, tels. la Banque d'Orient de 118 à 117, et l'United de 13/32 à 3/8.

Ceux qui avaient conservé jusqu'ici l'espoir d'un taux modéré pour l'automne, devront probablement y renoncer devant l'évidence des faits. La Banque d'Angleterre vient d'être obligée de porter le sien de 4 à 4 1/2 pour cent, à la suite de l'augmentation au même niveau de taux privé à Londres. Il faut que cette mesure lui soit dictée par de bien puissants motifs puisque la proportion de sa réserve, loin de diminuer, comme on pouvait le craindre, a passé de 46 7/8 à 50 5/8%. C'est sans doute pour maintenir ou même accroître cette proportion que la Banque a résolu d'augmenter son taux d'escompte ; peut-être aussi redoutet-elle un drainage prématuré de numéraire opéré par l'Amérique ou l'Egypte. Ce qu'il y a de certain c'est que les affaires ne vont pas trop bien à Wall-Street où les excès de la spéculation pèsent lourdement sur le marché. Ici, d'autre part, le manque d'argent se fait cruellement sentir : on assure que les fellahs vendent couramment leur coton à ceux qui leur en offrent comptant 17 1/2 à 18 talaris. C'est là un joli petit intérêt pour quelques mois et il faut que la pénurie de numéraire ait atteint une phase bien aiguë pour en arriver à pareille extrémité. Ceux qui s'attendent à voir les capitalistes renoncer à de pareils profits pour immobiliser leurs capitaux en reports risquent donc de se tromper. Les valeurs égyptiennes à Londres restent sans changement, excepté la National Bank qui gagne 3/8 l'à 20 3/8 et la Delta Light qui perd 1/8 à 9 | 7/8. L'Unifiée tombe de 101 1/2 à 100 3/4. A | Paris, le Crédit Foncier Égyptien revient de 688 à 684 et la Land Bank de 187 # 185, tandis que le Crédit Franco-Égyptien progressé de 106 à 107.50. Quant à la Rente Française, elle tombe de 95.12 à 94.60, à cause probablement des évènements du Maroe, évènements qui peuvent engager le pays plus loin qu'il ne | le croit.

Nous nous garderons bien de faire des pronostics sur l'avenir immédiat de notre marché, l'expérience nous ayant appris que la spécula tion ne raisonne pas ses engouements ni ses paniques. Depuis quelque temps on croirait assister dans nos corbeilles du Caire et d'Alexandrie à un véritable bluff, organisé dans le but sans doute d'entraîner à nouveau l'épargne | et le capital dans des mouvements inconsi dérés. Un jour, tous veulent acheter et | le lendemain, tous veulent vendre. Que signifie cette comédie ! C'est là un fait à prendre en sérieuse considération, si l'on veut s'éviter des mécomptes, à la veille surtout du rétablissement du marché à terme. L'as semblée des agents de change du Caire s'est en effet réunie mardi dernier pour fixer définitivement les conditions de détail, que voici : Le marché à terme recommencera à fonctionner le ler septembre. Il y aura une liquidation mensuelle avec compensation hebdomadaire. Les agents et leurs clients devront verser une J marge en garantie de leurs opérations et toute défaillance d'un agent entraîne sa radiation de la Corporation. Une chambre de Compen. sation sera créée à cet effet.--Telles sont dans leurs grandes lignes les conditions de rétablissement du marché à terme. On critique vivement la hâte qu'on a mise à confectionner et à voter cette réglementation dont l'application fera bientôt ressortir les défectuosités. A Alexandrie on ne parle pas encore de suivre le Caire dans cette voie et certains 'même disent qu'on s'abstiendra pour quelque temps encore. En ce qui nous concerne, nous croyons qu'il est difficile de rétablir le marché à terme au Caire sans le rétablir également ici, vu l'étroite liaison des deux places.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est renseigné en hausse à 4 1/2 pour cent.

Av Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé hier de 1/8 à 81 3/4. L'Unifiée a perdu 1/4 à 100 3/4. La National Bank rétrograde également de 1/4 à 20 3/8. La Daïra Sanieh est restée avariée à 12 3/4. L'Agricole a perda 1/8 à 8 1/8. La Delta Light a été soutenue à 9 7/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Égyptiens haussé avant-bier de 1 franc à 684 et les Lots Turcs également de 1 franc à 166. La Banque d'A. thèmes avance de la même somme à 112.

lei, la réaction qui s'était dessinée durant la dernière séance, s'est légèrement accentuée aujourd'hui, avec une abondance inusitée de vendeurs. La séance a donc été lourde au point de vue des prix, mais est restée favorable comme affaires, les transactions ayant été nombreuses sur la plupart des valeurs.

Au demeurant, le marché, malgré des réalisations peut-être prématurées et la réaction de nos valeurs à Londres, a montré beaucoup de ressort, et les titres offerts ont été facilement absorbés ; pour quelques-uns même, la demande plus forte que l'offre, les a fait clôturer en hausse. Il est indéniable que nos valeurs n'ont pas encore atteint des cours assez élevés pour donner des sujets de crainte. Il est plus que probable même qu'ils ne s'en tiendront pas l", et ils restent, somme toute, aux prix actuels, susceptibles encore de fortes plus-values.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National Bank est ramenée à 20 3/8. L'Agricole mollit à 8 1/16-1/8. La Cassa di Sconto gagner quelques francs à 45. La Banque d'Orient continue à se relever à 118. La fondation Société Générale fléchit à 46.

Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire reprennent aujourd'hui encore 3 francs à 198. Le Crédit Foncier Égyptien descend à 680. Les obligations anciennes font de même à 303 et les nouvelles à 258. La Behera progresse à 20 5/8. L'Allotement est offert à 29/16 et la fondateur recule à P.T. 70. Les Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux se maintiennent très fermes à 2 5/8, tandis que les fondateurs reviennent à P.T. 45. Les Heliopolis fondateurs en bonne demande haussent à 12 3/4.

Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Baehler sont très mouvementés à 6 1/16 après être tombés * 5 7/8. Les Ninkovich remontent à 14 1/2. Les Upper Egypt rétrogradent à 3 et les fondateurs National Hotel restent en bonne disposition à P.T. 37.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land est réalisée à 2. Les Estates sont lourds à 0 3/4 ainsi que leur part à 3 7/8. Les Walker and Mei Marachi se traitent à 0 3/8 et les Abdy se consolident à 11/16.
Le marché des valeurs étant resté fermé hier à l'occasion de la fête catholique de l'Assomption, notre Circulaire n'a pa paraltre ainsi qu'à l'ordinaire.
Pour la même raison le prochain numéro ne paraîtra que lundi 19 courant.
Nous détachons de notre correspondance de Londres, les passages suivants :

"Comme les dépêches télégraphiques ont do vous en informer, l'évènement de la semaine financière a été la chute de nos Consolidés à des cours que l'on n'avait encore jamais vus. Toute la côte en a été déprimée et l'allure du marché est restée mauvaise pour toutes les valeurs, sauf pour les titres égyptiens qui conservent une faveur que leurs bas prix justifie. Cette dépression qui un moment a frisé la panique, est due aux nouvelles décourageantes que New-York nous envoyait depuis quelques jours, et à la baisse subite sur ce marché des grandes valeurs de spéculation. On donne aussi comme motif la réapparition des traités amé. ricaines, qui, comme on le sait, sont surtout destinées à procurer de l'argent aux banquiers New-Yorkais bien plus qu'à faciliter des opé. rations commerciales. Ajoutons que les baissiers d'Outre-Atlantique ne se gênent pas pour prédire les plus effroyables catastrophes, et le marasme habituel des Bourses pendant la saison des vacances aidant, ils ont réussi à jeter le trouble dans les esprits, surtout venant après la condamnation de la "Standard Oil Cy."
"Il faut cependant s'attendre à une reprise très prochaine, le gouvernement et quelques groupes fonciers étant décidés à faire tous leurs efforts pour ramener le Consolidé à un cours plus normal.

"Les valeurs égyptiennes ont conservé une grande fermeté, mais les transactions ont été peu nombreuses. Aujourd'hui la demande était suivie en National Bank à 20 3/16. L'Agricole a changé de mains à 8 3/16. Les autres valeurs restent en bonne tendance mais n'ont que peu d'affaires.
"Au sujet de la situation monétaire, elle fait naître beaucoup d'appréhension, et l'on est presque certain que nous sommes à la veille d'une élévation du taux de l'escompte de la Banque d'Angleterre.

"Il est vrai qu'à pareille époque, chaque année on voit les besoins monétaires grandir et l'argent renchérir, mais on ne croit à une détente que si l'industrie se décide à réclamer moins de capitaux,ce qui n'est pas improbable, | vu qu'elle doit payer actuellement très cher pour se les procurer."

On nous mande que les observations dont nous avions fait suivre le compte-rendu de la réunion de la Corporation des agents de Change, qui a voté le rétablissement du marché à terme selon les conditions que l'on sait, | ont été mal comprises.
Nous avons été et restons partisans du marché à terme comme étant la seule raison d'être d'une Bourse.

Nos critiques ne s'adressaient qu'aux conditions dans lesquelles le rétablissement a été voté et à la "Chambre de compensation". On nous dit que le Comité en a longuement étudié l'organisation. C'est tant mieux, et, si comme on le prétend, tout ira pour le mieux dans le meilleur des mondes possibles, nous nous en félicitons !
